title: Assassin’s Creed Shadows lives up to the series’ name
snippets: Assassin's Creed Shadows introduces advanced stealth and assassination mechanics, making it a challenging yet rewarding experience. This iteration is highlighted for its precision in gameplay, marking a significant achievement in the franchise's development.
summary: Assassin's Creed Shadows features new, advanced stealth and assassination mechanics, offering a challenging gameplay experience. It is noted for its precise gameplay, representing a major development in the series.

title: I’m still testing the new Razer Blade 16 and I have mixed feelings
snippets: The Razer Blade 16 has been designed as a gaming-focused alternative to the MacBook Pro, emphasizing a return to a thinner and lighter chassis. This design choice comes after its predecessor adopted a bulkier build, aiming to offer a gaming laptop that maintains a conventional laptop appearance and feel.
summary: The Razer Blade 16 is a new gaming laptop that aims to offer a thinner and lighter alternative to the MacBook Pro, moving away from the bulkier design of its predecessor. It seeks to balance gaming performance with the look and feel of a traditional laptop.

title: BougeRV’s telescopic lantern is ridiculously versatile
snippets: BougeRV's LED lantern, marketed for outdoor use, functions as a versatile work lamp suitable for various settings needing additional light. It is rechargeable, compact, and features three adjustable LED panels that emit 3000 lumens, making it ideal for illuminating campsites, workspaces, or engine blocks.
summary: BougeRV has released a rechargeable LED lantern designed for outdoor activities. It offers 3000 lumens of brightness with three adjustable LED panels, making it suitable for lighting up campsites, workspaces, or engine areas. The lantern is compact, enhancing its versatility for various lighting needs.

title: Judge saves the CFPB, for now
snippets: On Friday, Judge Amy Berman Jackson issued a preliminary injunction to prevent the Trump administration and the Department of Government Efficiency from dismantling the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) during ongoing legal proceedings.
summary: On Friday, Judge Amy Berman Jackson issued a preliminary injunction to halt the Trump administration and the Department of Government Efficiency from dismantling the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) while legal proceedings are ongoing.

title: Windows 11 is closing a loophole that let you skip making a Microsoft account
snippets: Microsoft has announced that in the latest Windows 11 Insider Preview, it will remove a bypass script that previously allowed users to set up Windows 11 devices without an internet connection or logging into an account. This change enforces the requirement for an internet-connected account setup for all Windows 11 devices.
summary: Microsoft will eliminate a script in the newest Windows 11 Insider Preview that enabled setting up devices without an internet connection or account login. This update mandates internet-connected account setup for all Windows 11 devices.

title: The 30 best Amazon Big Spring Sale deals under $30
snippets: Amazon is holding its Big Spring Sale until Monday, March 31st, offering a variety of deals that are accessible without an Amazon Prime membership. The sale includes over 100 deals on popular items, alongside a selection of low-cost alternatives.
summary: Amazon's Big Spring Sale is ongoing until March 31st, featuring over 100 deals on popular items. These deals are available to all customers, not just Amazon Prime members, and include a range of low-cost alternatives.

title: Elon Musk’s xAI buys Elon Musk’s X for $33 billion on paper
snippets: Elon Musk's AI company, xAI, has acquired the social media platform X (previously Twitter) in an all-stock deal. Musk, who bought Twitter a few years ago for $44 billion, announced the transaction values xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion, which includes $12 billion of debt.
summary: Elon Musk's AI firm, xAI, has bought the social media platform X (formerly Twitter) in an all-stock transaction. Musk, who previously acquired Twitter for $44 billion, values xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion, with the deal including $12 billion in debt.

title: Microsoft tests Quick Machine Recovery to restore PCs that can’t boot
snippets: Microsoft has begun testing Quick Machine Recovery in its latest Windows Insider Preview build (6120.3653) for Windows 11 devices. This feature, first announced last year, aims to enable IT professionals to remotely recover devices that won't boot, in response to incidents like the previous year's Crowdstrike catastrophe.
summary: Microsoft has introduced Quick Machine Recovery in its new Windows Insider Preview build (6120.3653) for Windows 11, designed to help IT professionals remotely fix devices that fail to boot. This development follows last year's Crowdstrike incident, aiming to enhance device recovery capabilities.

title: The Fitbit-to-Google account migration deadline moves to 2026
snippets: Google has extended the deadline for Fitbit users to migrate their accounts to a Google account until next year. This update comes after Google acquired Fitbit in early 2021 and initially set a 2025 deadline for account migration. This change was communicated to Fitbit users via email.
summary: Google has postponed the deadline for Fitbit users to switch their accounts to Google accounts to next year. This decision follows Google's acquisition of Fitbit in 2021, with an original migration deadline set for 2025. Fitbit users were informed of this update through email.

title: The Trump administration could green-light deep-sea mining for the first time

title: Researchers identify mutations that can lead to resistance to some chemotherapies
snippets: Researchers have discovered that mutations in VPS35, a crucial component in a pathway that uses reactive oxygen species (ROS) to eliminate cancer cells, can lead to resistance against chemotherapy. This finding may aid in identifying tumors that are resistant to treatments.
summary: Researchers found that mutations in VPS35, a key part of a pathway involving reactive oxygen species (ROS) for destroying cancer cells, can cause resistance to chemotherapy. This discovery could help identify tumors that won't respond to treatment.

title: Discrimination-related depression, anxiety pronounced among multiracial, White, Asian populations
snippets: A study reveals that over 50% of US adults have faced discrimination, significantly impacting mental health. Those highly exposed to discrimination are over five times more likely to show signs of depression and anxiety. Adults experiencing such mistreatment have nearly nine times higher odds of screening positive for both conditions compared to those who haven't faced discrimination.
summary: A study found that over half of US adults have experienced discrimination, which greatly affects their mental health. People facing high levels of discrimination are more than five times likelier to exhibit depression and anxiety symptoms. Those who have encountered discrimination have almost nine times the risk of testing positive for both mental conditions compared to individuals without such experiences.

title: Meniscus injuries may soon be treated by customizable hydrogel
snippets: A new customizable 3D printed hydrogel has shown promising results in preclinical trials for repairing various types of meniscal tears.
summary: A new 3D printed hydrogel, customizable for different types of meniscal tears, has shown positive outcomes in preclinical trials, indicating its potential for repairing knee injuries.

title: Cold plunges actually change your cells
snippets: A seven-day cold water immersion study shows it can boost cellular resilience and autophagic function, potentially aiding in stress management, disease prevention, and slowing cellular aging.
summary: A seven-day study on cold water immersion found it may enhance cellular resilience, improve autophagic function, which can help in managing stress, preventing diseases, and decelerating cellular aging.

title: Researchers develop new DNA test for personalized treatment of bacterial vaginosis
snippets: Approximately one-third of women aged 14-49 in the U.S. experience bacterial vaginosis (BV), a condition with symptoms like unpleasant odors and potential pain. Over half of those treated with the first-line antibiotic, metronidazole, face recurrence due to treatment failure. Researchers have now created a DNA PCR-based lab test aimed at improving treatment by identifying the specific bacteria causing BV, enabling personalized medication prescriptions.
summary: In the U.S., about one-third of women aged 14-49 suffer from bacterial vaginosis (BV), marked by symptoms such as bad odors and discomfort. Over 50% of these cases see a recurrence after treatment with the common antibiotic metronidazole. Researchers have developed a DNA PCR-based lab test to enhance treatment outcomes by identifying the exact bacteria responsible for BV, allowing for personalized prescriptions.

title: Why scientists are worried about weasels
snippets: Researchers have discovered that red meat, enhanced with scent oils, is the most effective bait for capturing weasels on camera traps. This finding aids conservationists in tracking weasel populations, as these animals are typically hard to photograph.
summary: Researchers have found that using red meat with added scent oils is the most effective bait for photographing weasels with camera traps. This method helps conservationists monitor weasel populations, which are usually difficult to capture on camera.

title: Artificial neurons organize themselves
snippets: Researchers have developed novel artificial neurons that can learn independently, closely mimicking biological neurons. These "infomorphic neurons" are used to build artificial neural networks that self-organize and extract information from their surroundings.
summary: Researchers have created "infomorphic neurons," a new type of artificial neuron that can learn on its own, similar to how biological neurons function. These neurons are utilized to construct artificial neural networks capable of self-organizing and gathering information from their environment.

title: Brain channels 'stopped in time' reveal chemical flow that enables learning and thinking
snippets: A new study has discovered findings that could help in the development of drugs aimed at treating conditions like epilepsy and certain intellectual disorders. These drugs would work by either blocking or opening specific signaling channels.
summary: A recent study has found potential in creating drugs to treat epilepsy and some intellectual disorders by targeting specific signaling channels to block or open them.

title: Smart textiles and surfaces: How lightweight elastomer films are bringing tech to life
snippets: Researchers have developed thin silicone films that can replicate sensations such as touch, flexing, and pressure when electrical voltage is applied. This technology enables the creation of clothing that simulates touch, touch displays with haptic feedback, and ultralight loudspeakers.
summary: Researchers have created thin silicone films that mimic touch, flexing, and pressure sensations using electrical voltage. This innovation paves the way for clothes that simulate touch, touch displays with haptic feedback, and ultralight loudspeakers.

title: New approach could treat anthrax beyond the 'point of no return'
snippets: Researchers have developed a growth factor cocktail that reversed potentially fatal cell damage in mice exposed to anthrax. This finding suggests the possibility of adapting this treatment for use in humans.
summary: Researchers have created a treatment that reversed severe cell damage in mice exposed to anthrax, indicating potential for human application.

title: AI meets oncology: New model personalizes bladder cancer treatment
snippets: Researchers have created a new model using AI and machine learning to predict chemotherapy outcomes for muscle-invasive bladder cancer patients more accurately. This model combines whole-slide tumor imaging with gene expression analysis, improving prediction accuracy beyond previous methods that relied on a single data type.
summary: Researchers have developed an AI and machine learning model that more accurately predicts chemotherapy outcomes for muscle-invasive bladder cancer patients by combining whole-slide tumor imaging with gene expression analysis. This approach surpasses the accuracy of previous methods that used only one data type.

title: PET imaging confirms direct involvement of dopamine in cognitive flexibility
snippets: Scientists have discovered a link between dopamine and cognitive flexibility, showing through PET imaging that increased dopamine production in the brain improves efficiency in completing complex tasks. This finding could lead to more targeted treatments for neurological and psychiatric disorders.
summary: Scientists have found that higher dopamine production in the brain is linked to better cognitive flexibility, making it easier to complete complex tasks. This discovery, made using PET imaging, could help develop targeted treatments for various neurological and psychiatric disorders.

title: Understanding the immune response to a persistent pathogen
snippets: Researchers have discovered that the immune system can identify and manage the dormant phase of Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite. This insight could help in understanding how to tackle latency in various nervous system infections.
summary: Researchers have found that the immune system can detect and control the inactive stage of the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. This discovery may aid in managing latent infections in the nervous system.

title: Global patterns in seed plant distribution over millions of years
snippets: A study analyzing nearly 270,000 seed plant species globally has found that environmental conditions and dispersal barriers significantly influence why some plants thrive in certain regions but not in others. The research aims to understand plant distributions and how these patterns have evolved over millions of years.
summary: A global study of nearly 270,000 seed plant species revealed that environmental conditions and dispersal barriers are key factors in determining why certain plants prosper in specific areas but not in others. This research seeks to comprehend the distribution of plants and their evolutionary patterns over millions of years.
